text_en: Neurocognitive disorders 599 Neurocognitive disorders Neurocognitive disorders are characterized by primary clinical deficits in neurocognitive functioning that are acquired rather than developmental. Neurocognitive functioning specifically refers to neurologically based cognitive skills and abilities believed to be directly related to brain functioning, including but not limited to attention/concentration, memory, language, visual spatial/perceptual skills, processing speed and executive functioning (e.g. problem solving, judgement). Neurocognitive disorders represent a decline from a previously attained level of functioning. This grouping does not include disorders characterized by deficits in neurocognitive functioning that are present from birth or that typically arise during the developmental period, which are classified in the grouping of neurodevelopmental disorders. Although cognitive deficits are present in many mental disorders (e.g. schizophrenia, bipolar disorders), only disorders whose core features are neurocognitive are included in the neurocognitive disorders grouping.
